member.summary: Algorithm that performs a physical simulation where nodes repulse each other and edges are springs.
member.remarks: http://profs.etsmtl.ca/mMcGuffin/research/2012-mcguffin-simpleNetVis/mcguffin-2012-simpleNetVis.pdf.

member.summary: Initializes this object.

member.summary: Performs application-defined tasks associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources.

member.summary: The current result of the algorithm.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.Update(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Updates the algorithm.
member.remarks: Is *always* invoked from the UI thread. This method should not block for longer than a few milliseconds or otherwise the UI might become stuck.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.AddNode(Metrolib.INode)
member.summary: Adds the given node to the list of nodes of the graph.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.RemoveNode(Metrolib.INode)
member.summary: Removes the given node from the list of nodes of the graph.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.ClearNodes
member.summary: Removes all nodes from the graph.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.Freeze(Metrolib.INode)
member.summary: Freezes the given so that its position doesn't change until the node is unfrozen () again.
member.remarks: Is invoked by the view when the user starts dragging nodes around.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.Unfreeze(Metrolib.INode)
member.summary: Unfreezes the given node so that its may change, if the algorithm deems it necessary, of-course.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.AddEdge(Metrolib.IEdge)
member.summary: Adds the given edge to the graph.
member.remarks: Edges may point to nodes that have not been added (yet).

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.RemoveEdge(Metrolib.IEdge)
member.summary: Removes the given list of edges from the graph.
member.remarks: Edges may point to nodes that have not been added (yet).

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.Charts.Network.Algorithms.ForceDirectedLayoutAlgorithm.ClearEdges
member.summary: Removes all edges from the graph.

member.summary: Overwrites the position assigned by this algorithm with the given one.

member.summary: The watermark displayed in the if no text has been entered. By default, no watermark is displayed.

member.name: P:Metrolib.Controls.EditableTextBlock.IsEditing
member.summary: Whether or not the text of this control is being edited.
member.remarks: The user can enter this state by double clicking / tapping this control. The user can leave this state by removing focus from this control (for example by pressing escape/tab).
Setting this value to false is interpreted as ending editing mode (and NOT canceling it). If it is desired to programmatically cancel editing, then shall be called.

member.name: P:Metrolib.Controls.EditableTextBlock.Text
member.summary: The text being displayed by this control. The user may change this text, however the newly entered value is only forwarded to this property when editing has finished, i.e. when: - The user pressed enter - The user focused another element If the user pressed escape, then editing will be cancelled and the value will remain unchanged.

member.name: M:Metrolib.Controls.EditableTextBlock.CancelEditing
member.summary: Hides the , undoes all changes (if any) that were performed since editing was enabled and displays the again.

member.name: T:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout
member.summary: Defines the parameters for the "force directed layout" algorithm. Runs a physical simulation of the graph where nodes repulse each other and edges act as springs.
member.remarks: This layout is used by default if none other has been defined.

member.name: M:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes this layout.

member.name: P:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.Repulsiveness
member.summary: The amount of repulsion that each pair of nodes enacts upon each other.
member.remarks: The greater this values, the faster nodes will move apart from each other.
Should have the same magnitude (more or less) than , otherwise nodes may fly apart.

member.name: P:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.SpringStiffness
member.summary: The stiffness of the spring (aka spring constant) between two connected nodes.
member.remarks: The greater this value, the faster nodes will move due to being connected.

member.name: P:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.SpringDampening
member.summary: The dampening of the spring.
member.remarks: The greater this value, the more two connected nodes will decrease their velocity.

member.name: P:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.Distance
member.summary: The desired distance between two connected nodes.
member.remarks: This property controls the spacing of the graph: The greater its value, the more nodes are apart from each other, in general.
This is obviously only a suggestion to the algorithm. Depending on the number of nodes and their connecity, nodes can end up much closer or much farther away.

member.name: M:Metrolib.ForceDirectedLayout.CreateAlgorithm
member.summary: Creates a new algorithm that realizes the layout described by this class.

member.name: T:Metrolib.INodeLayoutAlgorithm
member.summary: Interface for the algorithm that actually determines the positions of nodes in the graph.
member.remarks: An algorithm is required to present a that specifies the positions for each node. Nodes without an assigned position are not presented by the view.
An algorithm cannot determine the layout of edges. If this is desired, open an issue on github ;)

member.summary: Whether or not the calling thread has access to the resource guarded by this dispatcher.
member.returns: Usually a dispatcher is used to guard access to a resource, for example a FrameworkElement. When a method doesn't have control over the thread it's called from (for example because it's an event delegate), then it might want to check if if can immediately access the resource, or if it should delegate the access via .
True when the calling thread has access to the resource, otherwise false.
